content.text: JavaScript String Search

String Search Methods




String indexOf()
String lastIndexOf()
String search()
String match()

String matchAll()
String includes()
String startsWith()
String endsWith()

See Also:
String Tutorial
String Methods
String Templates
String Reference
JavaScript String indexOf()

The indexOf() method returns the index (position)
of the first occurrence of a string in a string, or it returns -1 if the string is not found:

codes.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate");

content.text:
Note
JavaScript counts positions from zero.
0 is the first position in a 
string, 1 is the second, 2 is the third, ...
JavaScript String lastIndexOf()

The lastIndexOf() method returns the index of the last 
occurrence of a specified text in a string:

codes.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("locate");

content.text:
Both indexOf(), and lastIndexOf() return -1
if the text is not found:

codes.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("John");

content.text:
Both methods accept a second parameter as the starting position for the 
search:

codes.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate", 15);

content.text:
The lastIndexOf() methods searches backwards 
(from the end to the beginning), meaning:
if the second parameter is 15, the search starts at position 
15, and searches to the beginning of the string.

codes.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.lastIndexOf("locate", 15);

content.text: JavaScript String search()

The search() method searches a string for a string (or a regular expression)
and returns the position of the match:

codes.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search("locate");

let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search(/locate/);

content.text: Did You Notice?
The two methods, indexOf() and search(), are equal?
They accept the same arguments (parameters), and return the same value?
The two methods are NOT equal. These are the differences:

The search() method cannot take a second start position argument.
The indexOf() method cannot take 
powerful search values (regular expressions).

You will learn more about 
regular expressions in a later chapter.
JavaScript String match()

The match() method returns an array containing the results of matching
a string against a string (or a regular expression).

codes.code:
let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match("ain");

let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match(/ain/);

let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match(/ain/g);

let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match(/ain/gi);

content.text:
Note
If a regular expression does not include the g modifier (global search),
match() will return only the first match in the string.
Read more about regular expressions in the chapter JS RegExp.
JavaScript String matchAll()

The matchAll() method returns an iterator containing the results of matching
a string against a string (or a regular expression).

codes.code: const iterator = text.matchAll("Cats");

content.text:
If the parameter is a regular expression, the global flag (g) must be set, otherwise
a TypeError is thrown.

codes.code: const iterator = text.matchAll(/Cats/g);

content.text: If you want to search case insensitive, the insensitive flag (i) must be set:

codes.code: const iterator = text.matchAll(/Cats/gi);

content.text:
Notes
matchAll() is an ES2020 feature.
matchAll() does not work in Internet Explorer.
JavaScript String includes()
The includes() method returns true if a string contains a specified value.
Otherwise it returns false.

codes.code:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world");

let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world", 12);

content.text:
Notes
includes() is case sensitive.
includes() is an ES6 feature.
JavaScript String startsWith()

The startsWith() method returns true
if a string begins with a specified value.
Otherwise it returns false:

codes.code:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("Hello");

let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world")

content.text: A start position for the search can be specified:

codes.code:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 5)

let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 6)

content.text:
Notes
startsWith() is case sensitive.
startsWith() is an ES6 feature.
JavaScript String endsWith()

The endsWith() method returns true
if a string ends with a specified value.
Otherwise it returns false:

codes.code:
let text = "John Doe";
text.endsWith("Doe");

let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.endsWith("world", 11);

content.text:
Notes
endsWith() is case sensitive.
endsWith() is an ES6 feature.

Complete JavaScript Reference
For a complete reference to all JavaScript properties and methods, with full descriptions and many examples, go to:

The reference inludes all JavaScript updates from 1999 to 2025.
